author: sky.cactus
content:
Are consensus clients *still* not building their own blocks?  I thought this exact situation has been brought up over and over again as something that consensus clients need to deal with?
https://twitter.com/eyalmarkov/status/1572616363054612486

author: sky.cactus
content: TL;DR: MEV Relay went offline, and people didn't publish *any* block because of it.  Consensus clients should *always* be building a block with local EL and comparing it to the MEV block (which in this case would be nothing).

author: sky.cactus
content: Am I misunderstanding the situation then?

author: pietjepuk
content: The biggest issue is when a relay doesn't respond to getPayload (i.e. you can get slashed if you build and publish your own)

author: sky.cactus
content: Right, but I don't think that is what happened here?

author: pietjepuk
content: That's what happened a few days ago with someone with detailed loggings

author: sky.cactus
content: (I'll follow-up with them in that thread to find out what the nature of the outage was)

author: pietjepuk
content: Based on this tweet alone I cannot say what is going on

author: ajsutton
content: The relay was failing to respond to getPayload.  All CLs will fallback to the local EL when it's safe to do so, but it's not safe at that point as you've already signed the MeV block. Yes we've had this conversation before, yes we've given this answer before. ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: Ugh, OK.  I assumed that failing to respond to `getPayload` while continuing to provide headers would be an unlikely failure mode, not the common failure mode.  ðŸ˜–

author: sky.cactus
content: It feels like that should be the one failure mode where most engineering time is spent to avoid.

author: jgm
content: Yep we're not only trusting relays to not be evil, we're trusting them to be technically and operationally competent.

author: 0xraino
content: I just thought of an interesting type of alert consensus dev teams could set up. Alert if your binaries are not being downloaded by the proportion you would expect given the graffitis you're seeing. So if new version graffitis usually grow at 2x downloads and something is off there, throw an alert. Idea here is to thwart a supply-chain attack. I think it'd be relatively easy for the maintainers of the Arch User Repository consensus client packages to perform this attack, for example.
